channel.description: Recent content in string on nathan naveen

item.title: Leetcode 1332
item.description: 1332. Remove Palindromic Subsequences This problem asks us to find all the subsequences in a string called s. s only contains the letters a and b. When we are doing this problem, the main thing to look at is that it says “subsequences,” not “substrings,” and that there are only two letters a and b. The difference between “substrings” and “subsequences” is substrings are consecutive letters, while subsequences doesn’t have to be consecutive.

item.title: Leetcode 1773
item.description: 1773. Count Items Matching a Rule The idea of this solution is pretty simple. We know that the array items has only 3 items. The first one is the ruleKey = "type" the next one is ruleKey = "color", and the next one is ruleKey = "name". We just have to set a index of each item to either 0, 1 or 2. Then just loop over each item and check whether the item[index] == ruleValue.

item.title: Leetcode 833
item.description: 833. Find And Replace in String func findReplaceString(S string, indexes []int, sources []string, targets []string) string { res := "" for i := 0; i < len(S); i++ { index := 0 // this is the index that is used for indexes, sources, and targets for i2, i3 := range indexes { if i3 == i { index = i2 // we do this because the indexes are not sorted } } if index < len(indexes) && i == indexes[index] { currentString := sources[index] isSubstring := true for i2 := range currentString { // checking whether the whole substring is equal if string(S[i+i2]) !

item.title: Leetcode 647
item.description: 647. Palindromic Substrings func countSubstrings(s string) int { res := 0 for i := 0; i < len(s); i++ { for j := 0; j <= len(s)-i; j++ { if s[j:j+i] != "" && isPalindromic(s[j:j+i]) { res++ } } } if isPalindromic(s) { res++ } return res } func isPalindromic(s string) bool { left, right := 0, len(s)-1 for left <= right { if s[left] != s[right] { return false } left++ right-- } return true }

item.title: Leetcode 459
item.description: 459. Repeated Substring Pattern The idea of this solution is any substring that is repeated throughout the string s has to start at the 0‘th index and end at another index, such as the 3‘ed. This can be shown by using a image. In both the examples the substrings that are repeated are green. In the first example the substring abc starts at the 0‘th index and ends at the 2’d index.

item.title: Leetcode 5
item.description: 5. Longest Palindromic Substring In this solution we dont have to check whether the palindrome substring is greater than the max length substring because the length of the substring will always be greater than or equal to the length of the current max substring. This can be show in an image: func longestPalindrome(s string) string { max := "" for i := 0; i < len(s); i++ { for j := 0; j <= len(s)-i; j++ { if isPalindromic(s[j : j + i]) { max = s[j : j + i] // getting the substring } } } if isPalindromic(s) { max = s } return max } func isPalindromic(s string) bool { left, right := 0, len(s) - 1 for left < right { if s[left] !

item.title: Leetcode 1016
item.description: 1016. Binary String With Substrings Representing 1 To N The idea of this solution is to loop through 1...N and then make the string by adding the bytes to a string called s. Then check if S contains the reversed string of the bytes. The string s is reversed by a helper function. func queryString(S string, N int) bool { for i := 1; i <= N; i++ { s := "" n := i for n > 0 { if n & 1 == 1 { s += "1" } else { s += "0" } n >>= 1 } if !

item.title: Leetcode 1704
item.description: The idea of this solution is to first make the input string lowercase, and then add 1 to an integer array at the index of every letter, a = 0, b = 1, c = 2.... item.title: Leetcode 1592
item.description: 1592. Rearrange Spaces Between Words The idea of this solution is pretty simple, first split text by space. We have to split it manualy and not use a inbuild function because the text can contain multiple spaces inbetween words, and we have to count spaces. This can be show in an example: input = " this is a sentence " inbuiltSplit = ["", "", "this", "", "", "is", "", "a", "sentence", ""] The Code:
